ORDER granting 42 Motion to Continue as to Rafael Saldana-Esquilin (15). Arraignment and detention hearing re-set for June 23, 2009 at 9:00 a.m.Signed by US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin on June 12, 2009. (McGiverin, Bruce) (Entered: 06/12/2009)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin: Initial Appearances as to defendants (15) Rafael Saldana-Esquilin, (20) Miguel Arroyo- Andujar, (24) Luis Casellas-Rivera, and (25) Ricardo Cotto-Villahermosa were held on 6/12/2009. AUSA Dina Avila, AUSA Mariana Bauza and PTSO Evelyn Jimenez were present. Defendants were interviewed by the Pretrial Services Officer. Defendants were provided with copies of the Indictments and were advised of their rights. The Court reviewed and approved the CJA 23. Defendants will be represented by a member of the CJA Panel. Government requested temporary detention. Defendants remain under custody.Government requested the case be unsealed. Arraignment and Detention Hearings are set for 6/17/2009 at 09:00 AM in Courtroom 9 before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin. (Court Reporter FTR.)(Court Interpreter Hilda Gutierrez)Hearing held at 09:33 and ended at 09:46. (mcv) Modified on 6/15/2009 to edit dkt (er). (Entered: 06/15/2009)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Motion Hearing as to Jose Rodriguez-Monserrate held on 4/20/2010, re: 725 MOTION to Withdraw as Attorney. AUSA Idalia Mestey and defense counsel Victor Miranda  were present. Defense counsel expressed that he prompted to file the motion, expressed his situation and requested to withdraw. Defendant, understanding counsel's situation, had no objection that new counsel be appointed. The Government is willing to extend an additional date for the plea agreement deadline for the new appointed counsel. Two discovery packages were delivered to counsel Miranda. After hearing the parties, the Court granted the motion leave to withdraw. A new CJA counsel will be appointed. New counsel will make arrangements to pick up the discovery at Atty. Miranda's office. The Court will recommend to Judge Gelpi to extend the plea offer. (Court Reporter FTR/bg, CD: Brenda Gonzalez.) (Court Interpreter Felix Toledo.) Hearing set for 09:00. Hearing held at 10:34. Hearing ended at 10:47. (br) (Entered: 04/22/2010)

**COPY OF JUDGMENT 2255, 12-cv-1528 (GAG), re 2214 COPY OF MOTION** JUDGMENT is hereby entered dismissing petitioner's 2255 motion. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 7/2/12. (AH) (Entered: 07/02/2012) (er) (Entered: 07/02/2012)

ORDER **COPY OF ORDER 2255 12-cv-1528(GAG)**ORDER denying 1 Motion to Vacate. Petitioner-defendant wants yet a further bite at the apple. He now wants the court to reduce his sentence of 56 months to 50 months, claiming that counsel was ineffective for advising him to accept a plea agreement which recommended more time. Notwithstanding, and despite any such ineffectiveness, petitioner has failed to demonstrate prejudice. In fact, the court in this case sentenced petitioner BELOW the recommended sentence stipulated in the plea agreement. Petitioner would now want a further 6 month reduction, but a 2255 habeas petition is not a vehicle for the court to  now reconsider and/or reduce its sentence. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 7/2/12. (AH) (Entered: 07/02/2012)(er) (Entered: 07/02/2012)

ORDER as to Javier A. Santos-Baez re 2263 MOTION for Retroactive Application of Sentencing Guidelines to Crack Cocaine Offense 18 USC 3582 filed by Javier A. Santos-Baez. The motion to reduce sentence pursuant to 18 USC sec 3582(c) is Denied. This defendant (as admitted in the stipulated version of facts -- dkt 987), although a "lookout" within the conspiracy, carried a firearm in furtherance of his organizational duties. More so, while he stipulated to a particular crack cocaine amount for sentencing purposes, he nonetheless accepted that he indeed participated in a large scale conspiracy which distributed for profit not only crack, but cocaine, heroin and marijuana. The Court is aware of its authority under the crack amendment. However, given this panorama, the court opts not to sentence defendant below the 60 months already given to him during his resentence (see docket nos 2253 and 2254). Defendant's plea in this case stipulated a 70 month sentence. The court nonetheless -- and over the USA's objection -- reduced it to 60 months, taking into account defendant's rehabilitation while under BOP custody (Pepper v USA). Any further discretional reduction is unwarranted in the court's view. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 10/22/12.(cr) (Entered: 10/22/2012)

ORDER: Denying 2427 Motion to Reduce Sentence - USSC Amendment 782 as to Ernesto Saldana-Esquilin (16). The court, in the exercise of its discretion opts not to reduce defendant's sentence of 132 months, to be served concurrently with his state sentences. The court notes that in this case there is a mandatory minimum sentence of ten years to begin with. Moreover, defendant in his plea agreement (Docket No. 1441) admitted in the statement of facts that he was supplied marijuana to the drug trafficking organization. He also owned the crack and cocaine brands. Further, he served as a lookout to the drug trafficking organization and carried a scanner to alert of police presence. Accordingly the court will not reduce the eight months of his sentence that would bring him down to the mandatory minimum of 120 months. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi (MET) (Entered: 11/05/2014)

Defendant was present U/C and assisted by the official court interpreter. No objetions to PSR. Motion filed on docket #2443 was granted. Count 1, Term of Imprisonment of 40 months; SRT of 8 years; SMA of $100.00; Counts 2, 3,4, 5, 9, Dismissed. Defendant waived his right to appeal. ORDER REGARDING SENTENCE - USSC Amendment 782 as to Efrain H. Perez- Rodriguez Dkt #2447 and #2458 motions to reduce sentence -- Denied. The Court has reviewed the parties' disagreement memoranda (Dkt 2467 and 2473). The Court in the exercise of its discretion opts not to reduce defendant's sentence pursuant to Amendment 782. The Court notes that defendant was a drug owner, more so, he served as an armed enforcer as well. These factors weigh against any rehabilitation on his behalf, and do not make him worthy for any further sentence reduction. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 2/2/15.(al) (Entered: 02/02/2015)

ORDER REGARDING SENTENCE - USSC Amendment 782 as to Rafael Ramirez- Trinidad (22) # 2452 -- DENIED. The Court has reviewed the parties' disagreement memoranda (docket no. 2487 and 2496). The Court, in the exercise of its discretion finds that a sentence reduction pursuant to Amendment 782 is unwarranted in this instance. Defendant acted as an armed enforcer in the drug conspiracy. More so, while at BOP custody he has engaged in conduct contrary to BOP norms, which indicates he is not taking his rehabilitation as seriously as he should, and hence has been disciplinarily sanctioned. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 2/23/15.(al) (Entered: 02/23/2015)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi:Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Rafael Cardona-Castro (34) held on 4/28/2015. Present were Mariana Bauza and AFPD Vivian Torralbas. Deft was present U/C and assisted by the official court interpreter. The Court explained issues on the case. The Government informed that deft did not comply with the SRT conditions imposed. Defense counsel did not contest the allegations but presented mitigation factors. After hearing the parties the Court REVOKED SRT conditions imposed on 7/21/2010. Defendant was commited to the custody of the BOP for a term of 15 months followed by an SRT term of 5 years under the same conditions imposed previously. The Court added as SRT condition that defendant shall reside 6 months in a residential re-entry center and for a period of 6 months thereafter, a curfew with EMD monitoring bracelet. (USPO August Castro)(Court Reporter Evilys Carrion.)Hearing set for 09:00.Hearing held at 10:29.Hearing ended at 10:48. Interpreter Marie Hernandez. (al) (Entered: 04/29/2015)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi:Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Jose Rodriguez-Monserrate (48) held on 12/21/2015. Present were AUSA Edward Veronda and AFPD Giovanni Canino. Defendant was present U/C and assisted by the court interpreter. After reviewing this case which involves a serious addiction problem, the Court gave the defendant 2 options as to revocation: hold revocation in abeyance modifying the conditions of release and to send the defendant to an inpatient treatment center or to revoke and sentence the defendant today. The government requested that SRT be revoked. Defense counsel was awarded a recess of almost an hour to discuss with his client (from 10:34am to 11:32am). After hearing defense counsel, the Court REVOKED the supervised release and defendant was sentenced to 8 months of Imprisonment, time served shall be credited; no additional SRT was imposed. Judgment shall enter. (USPO David Vazquez) (Court Reporter Evilys Carrion.)Hearing set for 09:00.Hearing held at 10:27.Hearing ended at 11:40.Interpreter Edna Brayfield. (al) (Entered: 12/22/2015)
JUDGMENT ON REVOCATION as to Jose Rodriguez-Monserrate (48), - 8 months Imprisonment, no additional SRT imposed. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 12/21/15.(al) (Entered: 12/22/2015)

ORDER RE: AMENDMENT 782 as to Christian Pagan-Rosario (8). Denying 2438 MOTION to Reduce Sentence - USSC Amendment 782 filed by Christian Pagan- Rosario; Noting 2499 Report and Recommendation on Amendment 782; Noting 2625 Supplemental Motion. Defendant Pagan Rosarios request for a reduction of sentence pursuant to Amendment 782 at Docket No. 2438 is denied. The Court, in its discretion, finds that a reduction of sentence per Amendment 782 is unwarranted in this case. The Court notes that Defendant Christian Pagan Rosarios conduct included possession of a firearm in heroin trafficking activity. His already reduced sentence of 115 months (see Docket No. 2317 ) is sufficient but not greater than necessary. Subsequent order regarding 782 Amendment shall be entered. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 5/31/2016. (MET) (Entered: 05/31/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Gabriel Rodriguez-Rosario (23) held on 7/14/2016. AUSA Elba Gorbea and AFPD Andrew S. McCutcheon were present. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. The Government requested the minimum of eight (8) months. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution was heard. Sentence imposed to be imprisoned for a term of six (6) months to be followed by a term of supervised release of eight (8) years. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. Defense counsel informed that defendant is suffering from constant pain due to a hernia and requested that he be provided with medical attention. The Court strongly recommended that defendant be medically evaluated and be immediately treated for this condition. MDC to be notified. (USPOs Neysa Quinones and Alejandro Martinez.) (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.) Hearing set for 02:30. Hearing held at 03:56. Hearing ended at 04:14. Interpreter Enith Valdes. (br) (Entered: 08/08/2016)

JUDGMENT ON REVOCATION as to Gabriel Rodriguez-Rosario (23): Six (6) months of imprisonment and Eight (8) months of supervised release. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 7/14/2016.(br) (Entered: 08/11/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Status Conference as to Ricardo Cotto-Villahermosa (25) held on 6/23/2017. Present were SAUSA Cristina Caraballo and AFPD Laura Soto. The Court discussed with the parties the mental health evaluation report submitted as to the defendant. After an exchange between the parties, a sidebar was held. The Court summarized the decisions reached - the recommendation made by the psychologist in docket 2770, as to defendant receiving a four (4) month treatment will be followed, therefore MDC, through its legal adviser, will receive a copy of these minutes so that the necessary steps be taken; the Court and the parties will receive an updated evaluation and prognosis at the end of those four months, after which any further determination will be made after  another status conference is scheduled. The Court ordered that defendant be provided four additional months of psychological treatment at Devens. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Change of Plea Hearing as to Pedro J. Perez-Escalera (42) held on 11/26/2019. Present were AUSA Cesar Rivera and Attorney Ian Garcia-Ferreras. The defendant was under custody, present in court and assisted by the Court Interpreter. Consent to proceed before a U. S. Magistrate Judge was filed and accepted in open court. The defendant was found competent to plea. The defendant was advised of the maximum penalties he is facing, his constitutional rights, consequences of waiving his constitutional rights and the applicable statutory guidelines. After hearing the parties, the Magistrate Judge will issue a Report and Recommendation to Gustavo A. Gelpi, U.S. District Judge so that the guilty plea as to count one (1) of the Indictment be accepted. The Court orders the preparation of the Pre-Sentence Report. Sentencing Hearing is set for 3/24/2020 at 9:00 AM in Old San Juan Courtroom before Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi. Attorney Garcia-Ferreras requested that the defendant remains in the jurisdiction in order to be present at the interview for the preparation of the PSR. The Court noted the request and recommends that the defendant remain in the jurisdiction, but informed that the final decision rests in the US Marshals Services and the Federal Bureau of Prisons. (Court Reporter DCR / Courtroom 8.) Hearing set for 10:00. Hearing held at 11:03. Hearing ended at 11:30. Interpreter Virginia Zetterstrand. (ram) (Entered: 12/04/2019)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Francisco A. Besosa: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Hermin Rodriguez-Monserrate (27) held on 8/27/2020. Present: AUSA Sean Murphy and defense counsel Miguel Rodriguez- Robles. Defendant U/C was assisted by the certified court interpreter. USPO David Vazquez also present. All parties connected remotely. The defendant waived his right to appear physically for his revocation hearing and agreed to proceed via VTC. Arguments for mitigation of punishment and defendant's allocution were heard. Having heard defense counsel, the prosecution, defendant and the recommendations of the probation officer, the Court determined that defendant violated the conditions of supervised release previously imposed on October 7, 2010 and REVOKED the term. Sentence imposed: IMPR.: Eighteen (18) months to be served consecutively with the term imposed in Case No. 3:19-cr-00071-1(FAB). No additional SRT was imposed. Motion for reconsideration of the sentence imposed was DENIED. (Court Reporter Joe Reynosa.)Hearing set for 02:30.Hearing held at 03:37.Hearing ended at 04:09. Interpreter Mayra Cardona. (grf) (Entered: 08/27/2020)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Initial Appearance on Revocation of Supervised Release as to Miguel Arroyo-Andyjar (20) held on 4/14/2021. AUSA Scott H. Anderson and AFPD Victor Gonzalez were present. Defendant was under custody, present and assisted by a certified court interpreter. All parties were present via VTC. Defendant voluntarily consented to the holding of the hearing via VTC. Defendant was advised of the alleged SRT violations filed at ECF No. 3100 and his right to a preliminary hearing to determine whether his supervised release conditions have been violated. The Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. CJA Counsel Raul S. Mariani Franco was assigned to represent the defendant. Defendant was ordered temporarily detained. A Preliminary Revocation Hearing is set for 4/28/2021 at 3:00 PM via VTC before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez. If the government intends to call a witness that is not fluent in the English language, failure of the government to timely retain the services of an interpreter may result in the imposition of sanctions. Pursuant to the Due Process Protections Act, Pub. L. No. 116-182, 134 Stat. 894 (Oct. 21, 2020) and Rule 5(f) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, the United States is reminded of its obligation to disclose in a timely manner all exculpatory evidence to the defendant|s], that is, all evidence that is favorable to the defendant[s] or tends to cast doubt on the United States case, as required by Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963) and its progeny. Failure to comply with this order may result in consequences, including, but not limited to, the exclusion of evidence, dismissal of the revocation proceedings regarding the alleged supervised release violations, contempt proceedings, disciplinary action, and/or sanctions by the Court. (Court Reporter DCR/ ZoomGov Recording.)Hearing set for 02:00. Hearing held at 02:28. Hearing ended at 02:35. Interpreter Sonia Crescion1. (mig) (Entered: 04/16/2021)
